title: No Single Market Can Build a Circular Textile System Alone
content:
🧵 "No single market has scaled feedstock volumes or technology mix available to build a circular textile system alone."

— Kerli Kant Hvass, Aalborg University

At Nordic Circular Summit 2025, the Nordic-Baltic Textile Transition Group launched with a powerful message:

**The textile sector is in crisis.**

Overproduction and overconsumption have created a situation where end-of-life markets — reuse, sorting, recycling — simply cannot handle the volumes.

**The Regional Reality:**

🔹 80% of post-consumer textiles from Europe go to Africa and Asia
🔹 Multiple Shein/Temu planes arrive in Estonia WEEKLY
🔹 Separate collection mandate (Jan 2025) exposed massive infrastructure gaps
🔹 Local markets saturated by Nordic exports

**But here's why Nordic-Baltic collaboration matters:**

**Nordics lead in:**
→ Design and R&D
→ Emerging sorting and recycling technology
→ Chemical recycling (approaching commercial scale)

**Baltics still have:**
→ Production capacity
→ Manual sorting expertise
→ Reuse and repair infrastructure

**The Challenge:**

EPR schemes are being developed in silos. Fees are unrealistically low. Targets are unclear. Focus is on price, not impact.

**The Opportunity:**

By collaborating across borders — shared R&D, joint investments, harmonized standards, cross-border infrastructure — we can build what no single country can achieve alone.

"Trust doesn't happen itself. We need space to meet, learn about each other, understand each other, discuss the challenges and build that trust."

This is why platforms like the Nordic-Baltic Textile Transition Group matter.

title: Pre-Competitive Collaboration Works
content:
🤝 "Competing brands that would not in a million years sit together five years ago — they're actually quite willing to sit together now."

— Frederik Thrane, Lifestyle & Design Cluster

At #NordicCircularSummit, the Danish Voluntary Sector Collaboration on Textiles shared their most surprising learning:

**The pre-competitive setting works.**

Companies now recognize that circularity challenges are too big for any individual business to solve alone.

**What makes the Danish model work:**

✅ Voluntary but committed (signatories report progress annually)
✅ Shared 2030 goals across the industry
✅ Anonymized data for trust and comparability
✅ Small pilot projects where 3-4 companies tackle specific issues together
✅ Practical tools: recycled materials catalog, design guide, service provider directory

**The Three 2030 Goals:**

1️⃣ **Circular Materials**: 40% recycled content, 10% fiber-to-fiber
2️⃣ **Circular Design**: Products designed for long life and optimal loops
3️⃣ **Circular Business Models**: More revenue from resale, repair, rental

**Why this matters for the Nordics:**

Many companies treat the region as one integrated market. A shared framework could:

→ Reduce duplication
→ Create common expectations
→ Support cross-border operations
→ Strengthen our collective voice in Brussels

The Textile Action Network now connects national initiatives across UK, Canada, Switzerland, Germany, and Denmark.

Time for a Nordic expansion?

title: The Textile Industry Crisis No One Talks About
content:
🚨 The textile industry is in crisis.

And it's not the one you're thinking of.

At Nordic Circular Summit 2025, Kerli Kant Hvass from Aalborg University shared a story from 2017:

**The Story:**

A secondhand operator in Estonia had 50 tons of used textiles. No markets. Sent to landfill.

Why? Their partner was saturated with imports from Scandinavian countries. Local reuse couldn't absorb the volumes.

**The Crisis Today:**

💻 Ultra-fast fashion: Multiple Shein/Temu planes arrive in Estonia weekly
📦 Separate collection mandate (Jan 2025) exposed infrastructure gaps
🌍 80% of European textiles exported to Africa and Asia
📊 Recycling stats misleading: "88% recycling" mostly means backfilling

**The Uncomfortable Truth:**

"The majority of recycling consists of mixed mineral waste used for backfilling — which doesn't equate to high-value circular use."

**What's Being Overlooked:**

→ Preparation for reuse and repair has received almost no attention
→ Products don't get reused because they're dirty, stained, or pilled
→ These activities aren't done professionally at scale

**EPR Concerns:**

🔹 Focus on price, not impact
🔹 Targets missing, unclear, or unambiguous
🔹 Fees unrealistically low
🔹 No harmonization across borders

**The Question:**

"How do we design EPR schemes that fix market failures and enable true cross-border textile circularity?"

The answer requires regional collaboration, shared infrastructure, and honest assessment of where we really are.

Not just where we want to be.

title: Day 2: Nordic-Baltic Textile Transition Group Launch
content:
🧵 Day 2 Session Highlights from Nordic Circular Summit 2025!

The Nordic-Baltic Textile Transition Group officially launched from Nuuk, bringing together stakeholders from across 8 countries to tackle textile circularity at regional scale.

TOP MOMENTS:

🚨 THE TEXTILE CRISIS
"The sector is actually in crisis in many ways. Overproduction and overconsumption have created a situation where end-of-life markets — reuse, sorting, recycling — there are no solutions to put through these volumes." — Kerli Kant Hvass, Aalborg University

📦 ULTRA-FAST FASHION REALITY
Multiple Shein and Temu planes arrive in Estonia weekly. With separate collection mandated from January 2025, market failures and infrastructure gaps are now fully exposed.

🌍 THE EXPORT PROBLEM
80% of European post-consumer textiles are exported to Africa and Asia. What looks like "recycling" is often just backfilling. The waste hierarchy steps aren't happening in our region.

🤝 WHY REGIONAL COLLABORATION?
"No single market has scaled feedstock volumes or technology mix available to build a circular textile system alone." — Kerli Kant Hvass

The Nordics lead in design, R&D, and emerging recycling tech. The Baltics excel at production, manual sorting, and reuse/repair. Together, we have what no country has alone.

🇩🇰 THE DANISH MODEL
Fredrik Thrane and Jonas Eder-Hansen from Lifestyle & Design Cluster shared how the Danish Voluntary Sector Collaboration works:

• 40 company signatories (including competitors!)
• 2030 goals: 40% recycled content, 10% fiber-to-fiber
• Anonymized annual data reporting
• Practical tools: recycled materials catalog, design guide, service provider directory

"Competing brands that would not in a million years sit together five years ago — they're actually quite willing to sit together now."

🔑 THREE FOCUS AREAS
1. Reuse, preparation for reuse, and upcycling
2. EPR and DPP alignment/harmonization across the region
3. Regional infrastructure development for sorting and recycling

💬 TRUST BUILDING
"Trust doesn't happen itself. We need space to meet, learn about each other, understand each other, discuss the challenges and build that trust." — Kerli Kant Hvass

📅 NEXT STEPS
• Two online seminars per year on priority themes
• One physical event — Summer 2026 in Riga
• Host country deep-dives at each meeting
• Steering committee with members from all Nordic-Baltic countries

📧 JOIN THE COLLABORATION
Want to be part of the Nordic-Baltic Textile Transition Group? Contact Lifestyle & Design Cluster with your name, title, and organization.

Topic suggestions deadline: December 1st, 2025
